reviews.review_text: This game is not what it seems to be.   From looking at the screenshots, it would seem to be a good looking train sim, that provides an authentic train driving experience, using highly detailed models of real locations and real trains.  Unfortunately, and as much as I wanted to enjoy this game, I have found it to be a great dissapointment.  First of all, the game engine is a mess. Sure, the graphics look good when you turn everything up, but even if your computer was built by NASA you won't be able to, because it will kill your FPS.  So, turning the graphics down to acheive a reasonable FPS means that there are artifacts and graphical glitches... shadows that continuously 'catch up' a few feet in front of your train for example.  However, even when using minimal graphics setup, the game is FULL of bugs, glitches and other problems that make it extremely frustrating to use.   But it's worth pressing on because of the authentic 'feel' of the trains, right? WRONG. The trains in this sim are trains that I have been on thousands of times, when commuting from Brighton to London, for example. This sim fails to model the sounds and operating methods of these trains.  For a game that is supposed to allow you to control trains, there is an astonishing amount of difficulty in setting up your controls. They have gone out of their way to make this game frustrating to use and difficult to control.  Also, forget about gameplay. This sim is strictly about driving your train, with many scenarios requiring you to perform tedious 'shunting' tasks to assemble your train, a task made even more tedious by the games lack of user friendly options. The various scenarios are almost ALL BROKEN and have not been fixed by the publisher.  The publisher of this game charges a fortune for all the DLC, and it's broken, they don't fix things after it's released. Instead, they rely on the 'community' to add more workshop content for the game, which is completely ridiculous, like something a child would think of.  So, I am not recommending this game, unless you are looking for false promises and an un- authentic train sim.

TS has been the best actual simulator of railroads, but has offered numerous frustrations which I've tolerated. But upon hearing the release plans for TS2017+, I am depressed that it is no longer a viable use of my time and I have wasted hundreds of dollars for years for nothing.  I'm extremely disappointed in: - the yearly releases that don't add or fix anything for existing players, without requiring those players to fork over extra money for new routes - the astoundingly overpriced DLC which has many bugs - the extraordinary lag even on new computers with dedicated GPUs (you can disable lighting but that actually ruins nighttime visibility on some routes and actively removes scenery from others, making them as useless as wireframe)  But most of all, I'm disappointed that every bit of content I bought is now worthless in the 'World Edition' which we're being asked to buy. How do the developers expect me to keep gigs upon gigs of binaries & content which I can only play in my old version, and get a new edition comprising gigs upon gigs which I can only play separately? This demonstrates the utter lack of support for existing users of this product: the team has stated they're completely uninterested in backwards compatibility AND even in rebuilding prior routes -- such as, say, Northeast Corridor -- for the new edition. And if they ever DID rebuild a route for 'World Edition' you can guarantee it'd cost you tons of money to re-obtain it.  New gamers beware: I can't recommend buying 2017 because you'll have to keep it as a separate game and have to install a future edition that won't play any of the routes you received (or ANYTHING else currently available for sale - look it up, it's true). Existing gamers, which are bread-and-butter for competitor developers like Auran, already know that this team's behavior is pathetic. This is just the nail in the coffin.

OK, with 569 hours:  1. This is a marvelous game. Don't be put off by the DLCs. This is a train enthusiast's game; a hobby. Like a train set in your attic. If you want a new loco, buy it. Add it with pride as a new thing for your collection; it's not like a patch for a broken game. Buy a train because you like it, you want it - to look at, and learn about, and drive, and watch and hear rushing by. And if you want a route, buy it to EXPERIENCE it; spend time on it.   3. The experience can range from excitement of a high speed run, to a peaceful, even cathartic experience chuffing through hills and dales and towns and cities which so well represent the lands portrayed.  I cannot recommend this game more highly.

Updated 26 Feb 15 following comment and release of the Isle of Wight fixes.  You might think it would be fun, or at least different, to be able to drive a steam train, or indeed any train through rolling countryside, perhaps relaxing and a change from killing stuff. If so please look elsewhere.  The idea is good and I know simulations are not for everyone but the implementation is dire. There are repeated bugs and crashes and every update seems to introduce new problems without fixing the old ones.   There are 2 sides to this game. Driving stuff and building stuff in the editor.   Driving first.  Having never driven a train I cannot say if the simulation side is accurate, what I can say is that the missions and game play can be frustrating.   You get a handful of trains and routes from the outset and can purchase any number of additional DLC from Dovetail (or whatever they are calling themselves now) and 3rd party devs. There are missions where you have to take a train from one place to another in a tight time-table without speeding, falling of the tracks,crashing or going through a red signal which is harder than it sounds. Trains do not stop quickly, or like rain, hills etc so running on time is tough and it is very easy to miss a speed restriction resulting in a failure (or no awarded points).   Missions can last over a hour and you will loose if you go through a red signal, or make a serious mistake,. There is a quick save (press F2 - thanks paned) but to reload you have to quit the mission and then reload from the mission select screen. Some of these routes are very long and take quite a time to load. You only get one save slot per mission and so even doing a reload may not save you if you are about to pass a red signal. Get it right and there is a sense of achievement ( or relief ) but the bugs just get in the way.   There are other computer controlled trains on the line and you can be perfectly on time, top scoring only to have one of these crash miles away from you for the mission to fail. You did nothing wrong, the game bugged. remember how long some of those missions are? Imagine that happening 45 mins into one. It will.  You might like to purchase some of the nice shiny DLC, in a word don't. There is zero, zilch, nada, zip, guarantee that an update won't break it without warning, and never be fixed. When I first wrote this review in Dec 2014 the Isle of Wight career scenarios were totally bugged and would not load and had not since the 2014 update. Well at this has at last been sorted along with over 100 other bugs and glitches for one, rather old, route. OK congrats for at last sorting the problems devs, but you have released countless new bits of DLC in the meantime many of which have their own bugs.   One of my 3rd party routes (can't remember which) has you so that you are embedded in the roof of the train cab making driving 'interesting'. That broke in 2012. Since the original review I have found that some of the wooden post semaphore signals from the UK set have the signal arm at the bottom of the post (so embedded inm the ground), rather than where it should be at the top. I have no idea how long these have been broken, but given the devs priories (new DLC, new DLC etc) don't expect these to be fixed soon if ever.  Building  Hanker after your old train set, want to build a virtual one? Look elsewhere or the bugs and frustration will get you here as well.  The editor is complicated, and you have to do a lot of background reading before you start. Signals are complex things and getting them wrong with cause you no end of problems. This would not be a problem if editor loaded and didn't crash, and allowed you to move a track without sicking buffers all the way along it and has a sane way to build tunnels and didn't crash if you raised a track for a hill and... In short it's bugged as well. As for the documentation welll....  To sum up its a nice idea ruined. The graphics are nice (and bugged - check fully leaved trees that cast the shadows of bare branches, solid walls that have light flooding under their bases etc), and it could be a relaxing way to spend a few hours.  If it worked.

First of all, please note I would only recommend to an avid train enthusiast but not to an individual that knows nothing about trains. The base game itself is quite positive for those looking to have a realistic driving experience (3rd or 1st person), but the reason i advise non-train buffs to not purchase it is because of the amount of facts and figures you will come across and the fact that if you are not into it, then the DLCs are useless. The total DLC cost is well over a £3000 which makes it an incredibly over-priced game for what it is; a simulator. For £3000 you could buy a real train. Although, being an enthusiast myself, it is excellent to have a wide range of locomotives, routes and skin packs to be able to customize your fleet. A real con is where they sell you a train for £11.99 and call it new even though it has only been re-skined. Of course you do not have to buy every single DLC, but for instance I have spent over £150 on DLCs alone, way too much for a simulator. A good feature of this game is the create your own route feature. This is very complex but once you have learnt the basics, an excellent way to plan out a model railway. There are also modes such as free-roam (self-explanatory), scenario based, career scenario based and quick drive. Quick drive was added in quite a recent update and is one of my preferred modes; you are able to select any locomotive on any route, setting the time and day etc... Comparibly the scenarioes are excellent and with the addition of the workshop are seemingly endless. Overall, not a great game but don't allow the 200 and something hours tell you otherwise; please note, this was a big waste of my life and I do not want it to be yours. This game (even though I stated it was good for enthusiasts etc...) makes dept a real issue and if you're stupid enough to add all of the DLCs to the cart then you might as well get another bank account. I may play it an awful lot, but honestly the outdated graphics may be the best for a train simulator, but the development company to take over this game hasn't evolved since the 1998. The trains do look excellent, but the AI are all the same in effect only retextured to the time period or the characters gender. I'd say a 4/10 would be being pleasant to the developers but it isn't a good choice for Christmas. I grabbed this ages ago on hefty Steam discounts... It's a neat game, and there's a lot of great stuff here. But is it worth $60CAD? Heck no, not compared to so many other titles out there. Why is that? Because for AAA prices, I don't want to see 'ID Not Found' when trying to create my profile. I don't want to see lag or framerate drops on my high-spec'ed machine every time I pass through a town - and all the other little bugs. This is further worsened by the DLC prices - when they are priced the same as full-version titles, and I can read about how they have the same craftsmanship (aka riddled with bugs), I'm just not going to take the chance at getting burned.   And that is disapointing, because I like sinking my teeth in detailed sims; and I'm not afraid of opening my wallet and investing considerable sums into a game to support it... But when the title is riddled with bugs, the content (such as the tutorials) need further ironing out and so on, you cannot justify these prices - no matter how niche-market the title is.  I guess I can conclude this all by saying that in the end, I am enjoying it. A) because I did get the base copy and some DLC for cheap, and B) because my base copy keeps getting updated for free; so it's hard to really feel ripped off. So I am enjoying it - but I'm disappointed because I feel like my replay value is going to be capped until I can get some more DLC for cheap; because I won't be paying their regular price that's for sure.   I wish I could say maybe on the reccomendation... but it has to come down to this: until they drop their base prices for the game and the dlc to something more fitting the quality of the game you're getting right now, my reccomendation has to be no.  tl;dr; Great Steam Sale buy if it's dirt cheap (60-70% off or more I'd say). At first sight this game is everything you could want, it comes with a few routes and each of these contain a decent amount of scenarios which are mostly interesting and vary in difficulty. The graphical fidelity of this game is decent but this is 2014 and using 2D trees which rotate to look 3D in this day and age is pretty awful, overall pretty good however soon enough you will have done everything in the base game... so what next?  Well one thing you have to praise is the workshop which lets you download additional routes, scenarios and some other bits and bobs from other owners of the game which are free, and to be honest if this basic feature was not in the game there is no way I would be so positive up till now, so you have to give credit to all the people who have worked hard and given up their time making free content just to make the game more enjoyable, because the developers are too busy making the next stunningly accurate DLC to sell on the store.  Eventually you will want some new routes / locomotives to play around with so you will inevitbale consider paying some hard earned money for some extra DLC which you would assume will be a reasonable price.......... To sum it all up, this game is not a bad game, I have played some awful games and as a rail fanatic this game has done a good job of keeping me satisfied, however DLC pricing is out of touch and extortionate, usually not 100% complete or lacking fearues I would consider mandatory personally, the tools they have added to let the average joe create scenarios and improve routes whilst promising and fairly decent are tarnished by their incompleteness and are sometimes at best rather tempermental and require extreme patience. This review will undergo changes and be updated throughout my experience of the game.   Train Simulator (2014 as of this review) is my guilty pleasure, most of my friends and colleagues always shake their heads and ask 'why?' when they discover that I play this game, but my answer is always the same, and that is 'I don't know why I like this game, I just do'. I like all kinds of game genres (if not all!), ranging from RTS to Adventure to FPS and recently, Simulators, so picking up the TS2014 Steam Edition during the last Steam Sale was, in my opinion, a good purchase.   The game itself is a very mixed bag. Is the game compelling?  Yes . Are the graphics impressive?  Yes . Is the game fun?  It can be . Is it worth it's money?  Not exactly .  Train Simulator  (RailSimulator.com)  has become very popular over the years for many different reasons, one of the main reasons is because it is the best at acheiving it's set goals, it is without question the best Rail Simulator available as of this day, unfortunately however the game is also very, very famous for how over-priced its content is, having a number of bugs (first game I ever played it crashed due-to an 'AI Error' which I was in no way responsible for, now I save frequently) and unresponsive / unhelpful developers (Dovetail Games). Please do note that I am a developer myself so I understand how much work, time and dedication it takes to put a product together and that there is always going to be a likelyhood of bugs and issues that have somehow been overlooked, but when people inform me of bugs in my products (even though they are free to download), I get right to the task of finding them and fixing them! These are some of the main things that drag this game down, on the review page you will have to scroll for a very, very long time before you come anywhere near a positive review and even then it's likely going to just be a negative review in disguise.   I am not a diehard train enthusiast, I never have been and I never will be, while I have always had my interests since I was younger I just simply don't care that much for trains like a lot of the people who play this game do; For example, I see people complaining that certain locomotives only use a one-tone horn rather than a two-tone horn like they do in reality, and that kind of thing simply doesn't bother me. While I imagine it is a very easy thing for the developers to change and update (they really should do just to please the die-hards) it is not something I will lose sleep over... ever... but if people have to pay disgustingly large prices for something, that something should at least be done properly, right? While I am not a big train enthusiast, I do have my interests, I have always liked the thought of taking up Freight Train Driving as a real-life career, which I believe was the main reason that drew my attention to Train Simulator. I do not regret buying this game, I actually really enjoy it, but for quite a number of reasons, I would not recommend it...  The main reason why I wouldn't recommend this game is because of how overpriced the DLC is. I am aware and as are most of the  intelligent  people that the DLC available isn't supposed to be something that you're meant to collect the entirety of, you're just meant to pick out the trains and the routes that you want for your collection, that's easy enough to understand, right? Well, even with that in mind, the DLC is  insultingly  overpriced. It has been stated hundreds if not thousands of times, but DTG just don't seem to listen. The overpriced DLC wouldn't be too much of a problem if the base game itself was a lot more than it is. A friend of mine contacted me when I wishlisted this game and told me something along the lines of  'It is a lot of fun, but the game itself is very much like a demo. Unless you have money for DLC, it will lose it's charm fast' , and she was absolutely right. The version I have is the Train Simulator 2014 Steam Edition, it comes with a reasonable amount of content, but for the set price they're asking for, it's simply not enough, with that note alone I suggest waiting till this game hits another sale before any of you even consider picking it up. One of the trains comes with some scenarios, but it requires a certain route to actually play said scenarios which, for some reason, doesn't come with the base game which is just ridiculous. You pay for a game, you get some game modes and tasks, but in order to play them with the specific vehicle, you need to buy the route for an outrageous cost. That is just a slap in the face.  In my case, this issue is with the ICE Trains, you need to download the Munich to Ausberg route in order to play the scenarios. This route should be included with the base game if the trains are!   Thankfully, I have a lot of self control, so even though there are some routes and packs that I would like to add to the game, I will not go out and buy them at their insultingly large price, but at least wait till a sale (a very generous sale!) before I even consider the posibility of buying the pack in question.  With that said however and overlooking some of the tedious bugs in the game (which by the way aren't  all  game breaking, just a minor annoyance in my opinion),  I do and will actually recommend this game overall . It is good at what it sets out to do, it feels real, the physics and simulation are excellent and even though some people complain about the graphics, I think they're excellent.  If you are not a die-hard train enthusiast and can overlook some small issues and incorrections like me but are interested in buying the game, you should, but don't buy it at it's full price under any circumstances until the developers take note of all the bugs (whether they are small or not!). Do not pay good money for something which is broken yet can be fixed, but simply won't be fixed. Unless you have a lot of money to burn, steer clear of the DLC content too until the sales hit or until the developers decide to stop trying to turn this game into a cash cow and show some long-overdue respect to their paying customers.

Buying the class 390, Voyager 221 advanced and a commuter DMU such as the class 170 or 150 would mostly complete this route for modern day operations.  - Western Mainlines route from  JustTrains.net : the entire Great Western Mainline as far as Cardiff and Exeter, which is easily the best value for money of any UK route given the sheer length of track to play with, of pretty good quality. The 221 also fits here.   My general outlook on this sim is it's great thanks to its community. The only downside of the rich variety of realistic scenarios on the steam workshop is they often seem to require more DLC than you already have. The real opportunities for gameplay lie in the scenario editor and good third party developers, not just what you get with the game.

I got Train Simulator 2016 as part of the Humble Bundle for only a few $$, but I got the Humble Bundle specifically for this game as I was interested and wanted to see if 2017 would be worth the purchase.  Train Simulator is somehow really captivating. Everything you do in a train has to be planned way in advance as trains need a lot of time to slow down and stop or get going. It's also super interesting to learn all the signs and what theys mean. I thought as trains drive on tracks, it could not be that hard. But when traffic gets denser, all the buttons you have to press and signs you have to really look out for, it's harder than driving a car in my opinion. And more lives depend on it. So in principal I'm enjoying this game. But the technology Train Simulator is built upon is so unexcusably outdated, it sucks out all the air of an otherwise nice game.  Tha graphics feel very outdated. For a game that is Train Simulator 2016, or Train Simulator 2017 and costs $40, this is unexcusable. It looks awful. Passengers and their walking animations look terrible. Every few seconds the game needs to reload assets like trees and houses. And every time an object pops up on the horizon, the game stutters. And objects pop up in great numbers every 30 seconds or so, so every 30 seconds you get a huge stutter party for about 5 seconds until all new objects on the horizon are loaded. This is especially nerve wrecking when you're in a tight situation and need to slow down because of a distant signal, as the game doesn't always accept inputs at that time.  I also disliked the tutorial. It's not been given any love. The tutorial explains what home signals, distant signals are and what they display, but you cannt try it out. The tutorial is over after the explanation text disappears. This I could also read in the manual, no need for a tutorial mission for that that takes a long time to load. And that's it! Tutorials do not show you how the PZB signalling system works, when you need to slow down, to what speed you need to slow down, and how you actually do it. You cannot practice. This is only described in the manual or I had to look some additional YouTube videos, that did a better job.  Then, you're driving. And you come to the first yellow distant light signal, where you're supposed to slow down. You make a tiny mistake as you're not familiar with the buttons you have to press and bang, emergency brake. And the game doesn't tell you what you did wrong. Did I forget to press SIFA? Was I too fast? What would have been the correct speed? Tell me, I don't know! The game just lets you alone with all those questions. Very bad for learning and I found it highly frustrating. So you start the mission from scratch, wait on the loading screen for 30 seconds or more (and I have quite a fast machine) and then you drive for 20 minutes, until you make the same error and need to start over.  So, however interesting and fun I think Train Simulator would be, the technical drawbacks, long loading times, stuttering all the time, old and unappealing graphics, and bad tutorials / help system / explanations make Train Simulator an unsatisfactory and frustrating game.

A further problem with the loco is you can only get BR Blue lated headcode version as an undrivable model in yet another pack)   :(   I mean this is a classic locomotive that has not been improved since day 1. Early days but not so impressed with 'premium edition'.  The 'Academy' is quite poor - repetitive short scenarios which fail to properly explain controls, etc. The Academy contains only the most basic of instruction, no info that I saw on how to access various in-game menus etc., which I found later by pressing buttons to see what did what. The 4 included routes seem to conatin no tutorial missions. Nothing in the Academy, for example, explains how to properly use the dyamnic braking system. This is just one example; there are many things not explained. I've had several other rail sims in the past and even done some training as a fireman on real setam locos, so I'm not exactly a complete novice where it comes to trains - even so, finding it hard to control the trains reliably. There may be scope to adjust the control sensitivty, for example, which would no doubt help.   Career missions rated 'easy' are, notwithstanding the rating, annoyingly easy to fail completely. Examples include tight timing which has to be achieved or the mission fails - if you don't travel at or very near the maximum allowed speed you will be late and get penalties. No doubt that will improve with practice. It is possible to set up a 'quick drive' in which you have no goals, so one can learn to drive the trains like that, but better tutorial missions or a better 'Academy' which teaches more, rather being so reptitive, would give the novice player a better chance fo succeeding.   So far the game is tolerably reliable. The career screen, where you select route and scenario can be infuriating - I have yet to really determine how to reliably select the add-on package I want, it seems to reset them more or less at random. I've no doubt there's asome logic to it, but like the operation of the trains, it's not really explained. Nor did I find the 'manual' button did anything. I don't know if Steam installed manuals, but if it did the game doesn't open them.  I have experienced one crash to desktop, which I don't expect from such supposedly high end software - this was during a tutorial from the 'Sherman Hill' add-on; which does at least HAVE two tutorials, unlike the add-ons included in the 'premium' package. Of course, that add-on costs additional money, which doesn't bother me too much, but kind of makes me wish I'd gone for the basic game and then chosen add-ons I wanted.   With all that said, the actual graphics and simulation are pretty good. I have no real beef on that score, although the frame rate suffers a bit on my fairly high-end (Nvidia GTX960 4GB graphics, 8-core Athlon, 16GB main ram ) machine, when there is a lot of detail to draw, such as on the NJ lines with overhead wires and many tracks. I did have the graphics quality set to 'high', though. I couldn't see what the 'custom' graphics setting does - I was expecting a dialog to set individual parameters, but none appeared - so that I suppose is another issue.   Altogether, although the graphics and simulation seem decent, the game doesn't feel as good as I hoped it would, and in all honesty doesn't really feel like a polished, finished product. It's to be hoped that it will continue to be worked on and get better.  This review thing won't let me be non-committal on whether I recommend it. I suppose, if you like rail sims, I do: at least some of the issues will go away with further practice and more fiddlin' to see what does what. That said, if I were a complete novice at driving trains, I suspect I would by now be abandoning it. It would be better, rather than yes/no (or in addition to, maybe) if we coudl rate out of 5 or 10.

The amount of content NOT INCLUDED with the sim and only available as expensive DLC is pretty disappointing. The sim itself is already pretty expensive but to be expected to pay that price over and over and over just to pick up enough extra engines and stock to fill it out to where it ought to be is sad. The ONLY way to buy this is when it is on sale, otherwise you are going to pay around or over $200 just to get what should sell for $40 or so retail. What you get in the base package is not much at all.  That said, I am revising my review up a little because they have been fixing some of the glaring issues with some of the DLC so it is getting better, but it's still even worse than the flight simulator world where you have to buy scenery and airplanes separately to fill out the experience. But with those packages, they really do fill out the experience.  And now there is Train Simulator 2017 with still no mention of VR support. I suppose this title will continue to gather dust. It's OK, but not what it could be if VR support was added. I can only imagine what it would be like to look out over a freight yard in VR, see everything in full scale, have other trains pass within feet of your own, see the giant size and perspective of a 4-8-8-4 or any of the other big iron, etc. Yep, I can only imagine it because it's not available.  Trains are big and impressive and the cabs are just about perfect size for use with the HTC Vive. Not quite room scale but enough where you could set up a stool or tall chair, lean out the window, and hit the rails. Why is this not in Train Simulator 2017?  I'm qualified recommending this now thanks to the fixes but it still is expensive and really, really needs VR. Why watch a train when you can virtually drive one from the engineer's seat in full scale?
